learnContent.router: The router is the central hub of any network. All devices connect through it, and it manages the boundary between your private network and the public internet.
learnContent.unknown: Unknown devices should always be investigated. This could be a forgotten gadget, a neighbor using your Wi-Fi, or potentially something malicious.
learnContent.defaultPassword: Devices with default passwords are low-hanging fruit for attackers. Always change default credentials immediately after setup.
learnContent.iotDevice: IoT devices often have limited security features. Isolating them on a separate network prevents a compromised device from accessing your personal data.
learnContent.forgottenDevice: Forgotten devices are security risks - they may have outdated software, weak passwords, or be targets for attacks while you're not monitoring them.
learnContent.safeDevice: This device appears to be properly configured. Regular devices on your main network should be kept updated and monitored for unusual activity.

investigate.label: Investigate further

packetJourney.title: Packet Journey
packetJourney.selectDevice: Select a device to trace its packet journey
packetJourney.noFlow: No active flow data for this device

idle.link: Ready to trace packet journey using MAC addresses
idle.network: Ready to trace packet journey using IP addresses
idle.transport: Ready to trace packet journey through ports
idle.application: Ready to trace packet journey at application level

deviceToRouter.link: Packet leaves device with source MAC to Router MAC as destination
deviceToRouter.network: Packet carries source IP (device) to destination IP (internet server)
deviceToRouter.transport: Data sent from random high port to destination port (e.g., 443 for HTTPS)
deviceToRouter.application: Application sends HTTP/HTTPS request through socket

routerProcessing.link: Router receives frame, strips MAC header, reads IP destination
routerProcessing.network: Router performs NAT: replaces private IP with public IP for internet
routerProcessing.transport: Router tracks connection state for return traffic mapping

routerToInternet.link: New frame created with Router WAN MAC to ISP Gateway MAC
routerToInternet.network: Packet now has public IP as source, routes through internet
routerToInternet.transport: Port mapping stored so response can find original device
routerToInternet.application: Request reaches destination server (website, API, etc.)

internetResponse.link: Response arrives at router's WAN interface from ISP
internetResponse.network: Response addressed to router's public IP, port identifies flow
internetResponse.transport: Server responds on established connection (same port pair)
internetResponse.application: Server sends response data (HTML, JSON, file, etc.)

routerBack.link: Router rewrites destination MAC to original device's MAC
routerBack.network: NAT reversal: replaces public IP with device's private IP
routerBack.transport: Original source port used to deliver to correct application
routerBack.application: Response delivered to waiting application on device

complete.link: Journey complete - device received response via MAC addressing
complete.network: Journey complete - private IP successfully communicated with internet
complete.transport: Journey complete - full request/response cycle through ports
complete.application: Journey complete - application received server response

privateIp.question: Which of these is a private IP address?
privateIp.explanation: 192.168.x.x addresses are private - they only work inside your home network. 8.8.8.8 is Google's public DNS, and 203.0.113.12 is your public IP (how the internet sees you).
privateIp.why: Knowing private ranges helps you spot which devices are local and which are on the internet.
privateIp.nextStep: When you see 192.168.x.x, 10.x.x.x, or 172.16-31.x.x, treat it as local and find the public IP on your router.

macPurpose.question: What is a MAC address (Local ID) used for?
answers: Routing packets across the internet
Identifying devices on the local network
Encrypting your data
macPurpose.explanation: MAC addresses are unique hardware identifiers burned into each network device. They're used for delivering data on your local network segment - like apartment numbers within a building. Routers strip MAC addresses when forwarding to the internet.
macPurpose.why: MACs identify devices only on your local network, not across the internet.
macPurpose.nextStep: Use your router's device list to match MAC addresses to real devices when troubleshooting.

guestNetwork.question: Why would you put guests on a separate network?
answers: To give them faster internet speed
To prevent them from accessing your personal devices
Because there's a limit to devices on one network
guestNetwork.explanation: Guest networks create isolation. Visitors can use the internet, but they can't see or access your personal computers, cameras, or smart devices.
guestNetwork.why: Segmentation keeps guest devices from reaching your personal devices if they are compromised.
guestNetwork.nextStep: Enable a guest SSID and keep it isolated from your main network.

unknownDevice.question: You notice an unknown device on your network. What should you do?
answers: Ignore it - it's probably fine
Investigate and possibly block it
Unplug your router immediately
unknownDevice.explanation: Unknown devices could be forgotten gadgets, neighbors leeching Wi-Fi, or even malicious actors. Check your router's admin page to identify and remove suspicious devices.
unknownDevice.why: Unknown devices can indicate shared Wi-Fi abuse or a real intrusion.
unknownDevice.nextStep: Identify it in your router and block it or change your Wi-Fi password.

iotIsolation.question: Why are IoT devices (cameras, thermostats) often put on a separate network?
answers: They need special internet settings
They're often insecure and could be used to attack other devices
They use too much bandwidth
iotIsolation.explanation: Many IoT devices have weak security, use default passwords, or don't get updates. Isolating them prevents a compromised camera from spying on your laptop.
iotIsolation.why: IoT devices are common entry points; isolation limits how far an attacker can move.
iotIsolation.nextStep: Put IoT devices on a separate network or VLAN with limited access.

tenNetwork.question: What type of IP address range is 10.0.x.x?
answers: Public IP range
Private IP range for internal networks
Reserved for government use
tenNetwork.explanation: 10.0.0.0/8 is one of three private IP ranges (along with 172.16.x.x and 192.168.x.x). These addresses work only inside your network and can't be reached directly from the internet.
tenNetwork.why: Recognizing private ranges prevents you from assuming a device is publicly reachable.
tenNetwork.nextStep: Treat 10.x addresses as internal and look for the public IP on the router.

wpa3.question: Why does the staff network use WPA3 while guest uses WPA2?
answers: WPA3 is slower, only staff can handle it
WPA3 provides stronger encryption for sensitive data
There's no meaningful difference
wpa3.explanation: WPA3 offers better protection against password guessing attacks and uses newer encryption. Corporate data deserves the strongest protection available.
wpa3.why: Stronger Wi-Fi encryption reduces the risk of password guessing and data exposure.
wpa3.nextStep: Use WPA3 when available and keep WPA2 only for legacy devices.

printerRisk.question: Why is the printer flagged as a security risk?
answers: Printers can't be secure
It still has the default password, making it easy to hack
It's connected to the wrong network
printerRisk.explanation: Printers with default passwords are often targeted by attackers. They can be used to intercept documents, spread to other devices, or even become part of botnets.
printerRisk.why: Default credentials are a common entry point for attackers.
printerRisk.nextStep: Change default passwords and move printers to a restricted network.

corpIsolation.question: Why can't customers on guest Wi-Fi access the file server?
answers: The file server is turned off
Guest network is isolated from corporate network
Customers don't have the password
corpIsolation.explanation: Network segmentation means different networks can't communicate. Guests get internet access but are completely walled off from internal resources.
corpIsolation.why: Segmentation protects internal data even if guest Wi-Fi is compromised.
corpIsolation.nextStep: Verify guest Wi-Fi cannot reach internal servers or printers.

openWifi.question: What does 'Open' network security mean?
answers: Anyone can join without a password
The network has no firewall
The Wi-Fi signal is publicly visible
openWifi.explanation: Open networks have no encryption. This means anyone nearby can potentially see your traffic - it's like sending postcards instead of sealed letters.
openWifi.why: Open Wi-Fi lets nearby users observe traffic, which increases risk for sensitive data.
openWifi.nextStep: Avoid sensitive logins on open Wi-Fi or use a VPN.

evilTwin.question: What is an 'evil twin' attack?
answers: When someone clones your device
A fake Wi-Fi network that mimics a legitimate one
When two routers interfere with each other
evilTwin.explanation: Attackers set up fake access points with names like 'Hotel_Free_WiFi' to lure victims. When you connect, they can see everything you do.
evilTwin.why: Fake SSIDs can capture your traffic and steal credentials.
evilTwin.nextStep: Verify the official SSID with staff and turn off auto-join for public Wi-Fi.

publicPrivateIp.question: On public Wi-Fi, why might your IP still be private (e.g., 172.16.x.x)?
answers: Because the hotspot uses NAT and private addressing
Because public Wi-Fi always gives out public IPs
Because private IPs are only for home networks
publicPrivateIp.explanation: Public Wi-Fi often uses private IP ranges and NAT. Your device has a private address locally, while the hotspot uses one public IP to reach the internet.
publicPrivateIp.why: Private IPs can exist in public places too; NAT hides many devices behind one public IP.
publicPrivateIp.nextStep: Look for the NAT boundary: your device has a private IP and the hotspot has the public IP.

httpsImportance.question: On public Wi-Fi, why is HTTPS especially important?
answers: HTTPS makes websites load faster
HTTPS encrypts your data so others on the network can't read it
HTTPS prevents viruses
httpsImportance.explanation: HTTPS uses TLS encryption to create a secure tunnel between you and the website. Even if someone captures your traffic, they see encrypted data instead of your passwords and personal information.
httpsImportance.why: HTTPS keeps your data readable only to you and the website, even on untrusted networks.
httpsImportance.nextStep: Check for HTTPS (lock icon) before entering passwords or personal data.

vpn.question: What does a VPN do on public Wi-Fi?
answers: Makes your internet faster
Creates an encrypted tunnel for all your traffic
Blocks other users from connecting
vpn.explanation: A VPN encrypts everything leaving your device, not just web traffic. It's like putting all your postcards in a locked box before sending them.
vpn.why: A VPN protects all apps, not just browsers, on untrusted networks.
vpn.nextStep: Use a reputable VPN when working or banking on public Wi-Fi.

safeBehavior.question: What should you avoid doing on public Wi-Fi?
answers: Browsing news websites
Logging into your bank without a VPN
Checking the weather
safeBehavior.explanation: Sensitive activities like banking should wait for a secure network or require a VPN. Even HTTPS can't protect against all attacks on compromised networks.
safeBehavior.why: Some actions are higher-risk on public networks, even with encryption.
safeBehavior.nextStep: Delay banking or change passwords until you're on a trusted network.

welcome_hook.title: Your Network is Always Talking
welcome_hook.content: Every device you own is constantly communicating - your smart TV, your phone, your thermostat. But do you know who they're talking to, and whether those conversations are safe?

welcome_challenge.title: The Hidden Risks
welcome_challenge.content: Hackers don't just attack computers anymore. They exploit forgotten devices, weak passwords, and unencrypted connections. The first step to protection is understanding what's happening on your network.

welcome_mission.title: Your Network Discovery Mission
welcome_mission.content: In the next few minutes, you'll learn to see your network the way security professionals do - layer by layer, device by device. You'll spot vulnerabilities that most people miss entirely.

map_solar_system.title: Your Network as a Solar System
map_solar_system.content: This is your network, visualized like a solar system. At the center is your router - the 'sun' that everything orbits around. Every ring represents a different trust zone, and every dot is a device communicating through your network.

map_trust_zones.title: Understanding Trust Zones
map_trust_zones.content: Networks are divided into zones. Your main network holds trusted devices. Guest networks are for visitors. IoT zones isolate smart devices that may have weaker security. Understanding these boundaries is your first defense.

map_device_indicators.title: Reading Device Signals
map_device_indicators.content: Each device shows its status at a glance. Pulsing rings indicate potential concerns - a forgotten device, default password, or outdated firmware. Learning to read these signals is like learning to read a dashboard.

scenario_contexts.title: Real-World Network Scenarios
scenario_contexts.content: Networks come in many forms. A family home has smart TVs and baby monitors. A small business has servers and customer Wi-Fi. A hotel lobby has unknown guests on shared networks. Each presents unique security challenges.

scenario_select.title: Choose Your Environment
scenario_select.content: Select a scenario to explore. Don't worry - you can switch anytime to see how security concerns differ between environments.

layers_why.title: Seeing in Layers
layers_why.content: Networks operate in layers - like peeling an onion. Each layer reveals different information. Security professionals switch between these views to understand the complete picture. This is your most powerful tool.

layers_link.title: Link Layer: Physical Identity
layers_link.content: The Link layer shows physical connections - the raw addresses (MAC addresses) that identify each piece of hardware. This is where you spot unauthorized devices that shouldn't be on your network at all.

layers_network.title: Network Layer: Logical Addresses
layers_network.content: The Network layer reveals IP addresses - the logical addresses used for routing. Here you see which devices are local (private IPs) versus which are reaching out to the internet. Unexpected external connections are red flags.

layers_transport.title: Transport Layer: Connections & Ports
layers_transport.content: The Transport layer shows how data flows - which port numbers identify services (443 for HTTPS, 22 for SSH) and whether connections use TCP (reliable, ordered) or UDP (fast, no guarantees). This is where you see the 'plumbing' of network communication.

layers_application.title: Application Layer: What's Being Communicated
layers_application.content: The Application layer shows what's actually being communicated - web browsing, email, streaming. The lock icons reveal encryption status: HTTPS encrypts your data using TLS, while plain HTTP exposes everything. Unencrypted traffic can be read by anyone on the network.

device_inspection.title: Investigating Devices
device_inspection.content: Click any device to investigate. The details panel reveals everything: its network identity, active connections, and most importantly - security concerns. Red flags here demand attention.

device_risk_flags.title: Understanding Risk Flags
device_risk_flags.content: Security concerns are categorized by severity. 'Default Password' means anyone can access it. 'Outdated Firmware' means known vulnerabilities exist. 'Unknown Device' means it shouldn't be there at all.

device_learn_tab.title: Built-in Learning
device_learn_tab.content: Every device type has educational content explaining what to notice and why it matters. Use the Learn tab to build your understanding over time.

quiz_intro.title: Test Your Understanding
quiz_intro.content: As you explore, you'll encounter questions that test your understanding. These aren't graded tests - they're opportunities to reinforce what you've learned. Getting one wrong teaches just as much as getting it right.

mission_complete.title: Mission Complete
mission_complete.content: You now have the foundational skills to analyze any network. Continue exploring the scenarios, switch between layers, and investigate devices. The more you practice, the more natural network security thinking becomes.
